abstract: Performs a Quick Look on the content at the location specified by the supplied event.
overview:
## Discussion

The [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/EventType/quickLook] event type supports this method. The only valid properties of an [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/EventType/quickLook] event are [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/locationInWindow] and [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/modifierFlags-swift.property]. A Quick Look event does not come in through the normal event mechanism; therefore, there is no corresponding event mask for it, nor should you attempt to look for it in a [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSWindow/sendEvent(_:)] message or with the [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSWindow/nextEvent(matching:)] methods.

If there are no Quick Look items at the location, call super.

`NSResponder` declares but doesn’t implement this method.

# quickLook(with:)

**Instance Method**

Performs a Quick Look on the content at the location specified by the supplied event.

## Declaration

```swift
@MainActor func quickLook(with event: NSEvent)
```

## Parameters

- **event**: An event object containing the location of the Quick Look content.

## Discussion

The [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/EventType/quickLook] event type supports this method. The only valid properties of an [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/EventType/quickLook] event are [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/locationInWindow] and [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSEvent/modifierFlags-swift.property]. A Quick Look event does not come in through the normal event mechanism; therefore, there is no corresponding event mask for it, nor should you attempt to look for it in a [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSWindow/sendEvent(_:)] message or with the [doc://com.apple.appkit/documentation/AppKit/NSWindow/nextEvent(matching:)] methods.

If there are no Quick Look items at the location, call super.

`NSResponder` declares but doesn’t implement this method.

## Related Documentation

- **NSEvent.EventType.quickLook**: An event that initiates a Quick Look request.

## Responding to Other Kinds of Events

- **cursorUpdate(with:)**: Informs the receiver that the mouse cursor has moved into a cursor rectangle.
- **flagsChanged(with:)**: Informs the receiver that the user has pressed or released a modifier key (Shift, Control, and so on).
- **tabletPoint(with:)**: Informs the receiver that a tablet-point event has occurred.
- **tabletProximity(with:)**: Informs the receiver that a tablet-proximity event has occurred.
- **helpRequested(_:)**: Displays context-sensitive help for the receiver if help has been registered.
- **scrollWheel(with:)**: Informs the receiver that the mouse’s scroll wheel has moved.
- **changeMode(with:)**: Informs the responder that performed a double-tap on the side of an Apple Pencil.
